questions.text: Which antianginal drug is associated with an increased risk of bradyarrhythmia and visual disturbances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ivabradine
Explanation:
Ivabradine is a selective If ("funny") current inhibitor in the sinoatrial (SA) node, used to reduce heart rate without affecting myocardial contractility or blood pressure. It is used in:
• Chronic stable angina in patients who cannot tolerate beta-blockers.
• Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) in select patients.
Associated Adverse Effects:
• Bradyarrhythmias: Due to excessive slowing of SA node activity.
• Visual disturbances ("phosphenes"): Patients often report transient enhanced brightness in part of their visual field, related to ivabradine’s action on retinal ion channels (which are similar to those in the SA node).
 Other options:
B) Nicorandil:
o Potassium channel opener and nitrate-like drug.
o Can cause headache and ulcers, but not bradycardia or visual changes.
C) Ranolazine:
o Inhibits late sodium current.
o May prolong QT interval but does not typically cause bradycardia or visual symptoms.
D) Amlodipine:
o A dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker.
o Can cause edema, flushing, constipation and ankle edema but not visual disturbances

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with pheochromocytoma and is given a medication to manage hypertension and symptoms related to excess catecholamines. Which drug works by inhibiting the rate limiting step in the synthesis of norepinephrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Metyrosine

Explanation:
Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor (usually of the adrenal medulla), causing excess production of epinephrine and norepinephrine, leading to hypertension, palpitations, sweating, and headache.
Mechanism of Action of Metyrosine:
Metyrosine (also known as α-methyltyrosine) inhibits the rate-limiting step in catecholamine synthesis:
o It inhibits tyrosine hydroxylase, the enzyme that converts tyrosine → DOPA.
o This reduces the synthesis of dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine.
Other options:
a) Reserpine:
o Inhibits VMAT (vesicular monoamine transporter), preventing storage of norepinephrine in vesicles.
o Depletes monoamines but does not inhibit synthesis.
c) Clonidine:
o Alpha-2 agonist in the CNS, reducing sympathetic outflow.
o Lowers BP but does not affect catecholamine synthesis directly.
d) Phentolamine:
o Non-selective alpha blocker, used to manage hypertensive crises in pheochromocytoma.
o Works by blocking alpha receptors, not by inhibiting synthesis.

choices.text: Drugs with large Vd can be removed by dialysis
If Vd is large most of the drug remains in the plasma compartment
A highly ionised drug has low Vd

questions.text: Which one of the following is a true statement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A highly ionised drug has low Vd

Explanation:
Volume of distribution (Vd) refers to the theoretical volume that would be necessary to contain the total amount of a drug in the body at the same concentration as in the plasma.
Correct statement:
C. A highly ionised drug has low Vd- True.
Ionised (charged) drugs are usually water-soluble and do not easily cross lipid membranes to enter tissues.
As a result, they tend to remain in the plasma and extracellular fluid, resulting in a low Vd.

Incorrect statements:
• A. Drugs with large Vd can be removed by dialysis- False.
Drugs with a large Vd are extensively distributed into tissues, leaving less drug in the plasma. Dialysis primarily clears drugs from the blood/plasma, so drugs with large Vd are poorly removed by dialysis.
• B. If Vd is large most of the drug remains in the plasma compartment- False.
Large Vd means the drug leaves the plasma and distributes extensively into tissues and fat. So, less of the drug is in plasma.
• D. Digoxin has low Vd-  False.
Digoxin has a very large Vd (~6–7 L/kg), because it extensively binds to tissues, especially cardiac and skeletal muscle

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with neurogenic orthostatic hypotension is experiencing significant symptoms despite lifestyle modifications. Which medication is often used orally as a first-line treatment to increase blood pressure and improve symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Midodrine
Explanation:
Neurogenic orthostatic hypotension (nOH) is caused by impaired autonomic nervous system function, leading to inadequate vasoconstriction when standing. This results in a significant drop in blood pressure, causing dizziness, lightheadedness, or syncope.

Midodrine is:
• A prodrug converted to desglymidodrine, an alpha-1 adrenergic agonist.
• It causes vasoconstriction, thereby increasing blood pressure.
• Commonly used as first-line oral therapy for symptomatic nOH.
• Administered during the daytime (not at bedtime) to avoid supine hypertension.

 Other options:
b) Propranolol:
o A non-selective beta-blocker. It can actually worsen orthostatic hypotension due to reduced cardiac output.
c) Dobutamine:
o A beta-1 agonist used IV in acute heart failure. Not suitable for chronic oral management of hypotension.
d) Clonidine:
o An alpha-2 agonist, which reduces sympathetic outflow. It is used to lower blood pressure, not raise it.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with type 2 diabetes and a history of bladder cancer is concerned about their medication. Which of the following drugs would be least appropriate for them?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Pioglitazone
Explanation:
Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione (TZD) used to improve insulin sensitivity in type 2 diabetes. However, its use is associated with an increased risk of bladder cancer, especially with long-term use or higher cumulative doses.
Why Pioglitazone is Least Appropriate in This Patient:
• The patient has a history of bladder cancer.
• Pioglitazone is contraindicated or should be avoided in patients with active bladder cancer or a history of bladder cancer due to this risk.
• The FDA has issued warnings about this association.
Other options:
A) Metformin
o First-line drug for type 2 diabetes.
o No known association with bladder cancer.
o Generally safe unless contraindicated by renal dysfunction or risk of lactic acidosis.
B) Sitagliptin
o A DPP-4 inhibitor.
o No association with bladder cancer.
D) Empagliflozin
o An SGLT2 inhibitor.
o No established link with bladder cancer.
o Caution with genitourinary infections, but not specifically bladder cancer.

choices.text: Transport of glucose from the intestinal lumen into intestinal epithelial cell is by facilitated diffusion
Transport of glucose into adipocytes is by facilitated diffusion
Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-dependent counter transport

questions.text: Given below are four examples of transport across the cell membrane with the type of transport. Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal epithelial cells is by Na+- glucose co-transport, an example of secondary active co-transport. Glucose is transported into adipocytes by insulin-dependent facilitated diffusion. Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-Ca++ antiport, which is an example of secondary active counter transport. During the depolarization phase of the action potential opening of voltage gated sodium channels allows the influx of sodium. Transport through channels is an example of simple diffusion.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used as an antidote for cisplatin induced nephrotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

. Amifostine
Explanation:
Cisplatin is a chemotherapy agent commonly used in the treatment of various cancers, but one of its major dose-limiting toxicities is nephrotoxicity (kidney damage).
Amifostine:
• A cytoprotective agent used to reduce cisplatin-induced nephrotoxicity.
• It is a prodrug that is dephosphorylated by alkaline phosphatase to an active free thiol metabolite, which scavenges free radicals and binds toxic platinum metabolites in renal tissue.
• FDA-approved for use with cisplatin to protect normal tissues (especially kidneys).
Other options:
a. Mesna
o Used to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis caused by ifosfamide and cyclophosphamide, not nephrotoxicity.
c. Leucovorin (folinic acid)
o Used to rescue normal cells from methotrexate toxicity or to enhance the effect of 5-FU, not nephroprotection.
d. Filgrastim
o A G-CSF (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor) used to treat or prevent neutropenia, especially during chemotherapy.
o Not protective against nephrotoxicity.

questions.text: A 12 year child presents with mental retardation and history of self mutilation. Which of the following tests will help in determining the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is a rare metabolic disorder that primarily affects males and is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HPRT). This condition leads to neurological and behavioral abnormalities, including severe self-injury, poor muscle control, and mental disabilities. Additionally, it is characterized by the overproduction of uric acid, which can result in gout and kidney problems. Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and preventing self-injury, as there is currently no cure for the syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is an FDA-approved treatment for postpartum depression?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Brexanolone
Explanation:
Brexanolone is the first FDA-approved medication specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression (PPD).
• It is a neuroactive steroid and a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors.
• Administered as a 60-hour continuous intravenous infusion in a certified healthcare facility.
• Approved by the FDA in 2019 for postpartum depression in adult women.
Other options:
B) Duloxetine
o An SNRI used for major depressive disorder, anxiety, and pain, but not specifically approved for PPD.
C) Bupropion
o An NDRI (norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor), used in depression and smoking cessation.
o Not approved for PPD.
D) Venlafaxine
o Another SNRI used for major depressive disorder, but again, not FDA-approved for PPD.

questions.text: Which of the following elements is known to influence the body's ability to handle oxidative stress?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

As an essential trace element, the importance of selenium (Se) in humans is well established, and its deficiency has caused serious health effects in humans, such as Keshan disease. Foods are major natural source of Se, and its levels generally depend on soil Se levels. Since its discovery as an important component of antioxidant enzymes, such as glutathione peroxidase (GPx), thioredoxin reductase (TrxR) and iodothyronine deiodinases (IDD), there has been an increased interest in the study of other Se-containing proteins (selenoproteins) or enzymes (selenoenzymes)

questions.text: Which drug is FDA-approved for reducing abdominal fat in HIV-associated lipodystrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Tesamorelin
Explanation:
Tesamorelin is an FDA-approved drug for:
Reducing abdominal (visceral) fat in patients with HIV-associated lipodystrophy
Mechanism of Action:
• Tesamorelin is a synthetic analog of growth hormone-releasing hormone (GHRH).
• It stimulates the pituitary gland to release growth hormone, which in turn:
o Reduces visceral adipose tissue (VAT).
o Improves body composition in patients with HIV-associated lipodystrophy.
Incorrect options:
A) Somatropin
o Recombinant human growth hormone.
o Used in growth hormone deficiency, not specifically approved for HIV lipodystrophy.
C) Pegvisomant
o A growth hormone receptor antagonist, used in acromegaly.
o It blocks GH action, opposite of what’s needed in lipodystrophy.
D) Mecasermin
o Recombinant IGF-1, used in IGF-1 deficiency, particularly in pediatric growth disorders.
o Not used for fat redistribution.

questions.text: Which drug is a neurokinin-1 (NK-1) antagonist used for chemotherapy-induced nausea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aprepitant
Explanation:
Aprepitant is a neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptor antagonist used primarily for: delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), especially with highly emetogenic chemotherapy.
Mechanism of Action:
• It blocks the NK-1 receptors in the brainstem (area postrema and nucleus tractus solitarius), where substance P acts to induce vomiting.
• Often used in combination with:
o A 5-HT3 antagonist (e.g., ondansetron or palonosetron)
o A corticosteroid (e.g., dexamethasone)
Incorrect options:
a) Ondansetron
o A 5-HT3 receptor antagonist
o Very effective for acute CINV, but not NK-1 related
c) Metoclopramide
o A D2 receptor antagonist (and also 5-HT4 agonist)
o Used for gastroparesis and mild nausea, not as potent for CINV
d) Palonosetron
o A long-acting 5-HT3 antagonist
o Used for acute and delayed CINV, but again, not an NK-1 antagonist

questions.text: The following diagram shows the changes in hypothalamic set point and body temperature during fever. Which of the following hypothalamic nuclei will be activated at point B as compared to point A?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is having diarrhoea for 2 years, a biopsy suspicious of celiac disease, a peripheral blood smear examination shows dimorphic anemia. Which of the following deficiency is the most likely cause for such blood picture?

 Iron and folic acid. Celiac disease causes malabsorption from upper GIT iron is predominantly absorbed in Duodenum (Proximal intestine) and Folic acid in Jejunum thus co-existence is more common. While vitamin B12 is absorbed from terminal ileum, celiac doesn’t involve ileum. Iron and B12 deficiency can coexist in Crohn disease, tuberculosis ulcers of ileum ( ulcers leading to bleeding and ileal disease leading to malabsorption of B12 and even in  post gastrectomy ( IF deficiency leads to B12 deficiency and achlorhydria can lead to iron malabsorption.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with severe pain, crepitus, and swelling over the thigh 2 days after a crush injury. There is brownish discharge with a foul odour. What is the virulence factor responsible for tissue destruction?

• Alpha toxin = lecithinase, destroys phospholipids in cell membranes → tissue necrosis.

• Treatment: Surgical debridement + penicillin + hyperbaric oxygen.

questions.text: A Child underwent tonsillectomy and after surgery shifted to recovery room where he started bleeding and on examination a clot was seen at the site of surgery. Next step in management will be ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Shift patient to OT and ligation bleeding vessel
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Primary haemorrhage. 
• Occurs at the time of operation.
• It can be controlled by pressure, ligation or electrocoagulation of the bleeding vessels.

Reactionary haemorrhage. 
• Occurs within a period of 24 h and can be controlled by simple measures such as removal of the clot, application of pressure or vasoconstrictor.
• Presence of a clot prevents the clipping action of the superior constrictor muscle on the vessels which pass through it (compare postpartum uterine bleeding).
Secondary haemorrhage. 
• Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. 
• It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane.

questions.text: Cannon “a” wave on the JVP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 AV dissociation.

The positive presystolic a wave is produced by venous distention due to right atrial contraction and is the dominant wave in the JVP, particularly during inspiration. 
Large ‘a’ waves indicate that the right atrium is contracting against an increased resistance, such as occurs with tricuspid stenosis or more commonly with increased resistance to right ventricular filling (pulmonary hypertension or pulmonic stenosis). Large a waves also occur during arrhythmias whenever the right atrium contracts while the tricuspid valve is closed by right ventricular systole. 
“Cannon” a waves may occur regularly (as during junctional rhythm)or irregularly (as in atrioventricular dissociation with ventricular tachycardia or complete heart block). 
The a wave is absent in patients with atrial fibrillation, and there is an increased delay between the a wave and the carotid arterial pulse in patients with first-degree atrioventricular block.

Endophthalmitis classically is seen after 3 days of cataract surgery, in which infection/inflammation is in the vitreous as well (USG B scan will give abnormal results)

Bullous keratopathy is a pathological condition in which small vesicles, or bullae, are formed in the epithelial layer of cornea due to endothelial dysfunction. It can happen after complicated cataract surgery, so also known as pseudophakic/aphakic bullous keratpathy.

Pseudophakic Cystoid macular edema (Irvine Gass Syndrome) is thought to be due to upregulation of inflammatory mediators in the aqueous and vitreous humors after surgical manipulation. Inflammation breaks down the blood-aqueous and blood-retinal-barriers, which leads to increased vascular permeability.

questions.text: Which anti diabetes agents can be useful in hepatic encephalopathy

As a result, the ratio of saccharolytic to proteolytic bacterial flora is increased, and blood ammonia levels are decreased

questions.text: Which of the following patients with Parkinson disease is the best candidate for deep brain stimulation?

Most surgical procedures for PD performed today utilize deep brain stimulation (DBS). Here, an electrode is placed into the target area and connected to a stimulator inserted SC over the chest wall. DBS simulates the effects of a lesion without necessitating a brain lesion. 
The procedure is thus primarily indicated for patients who suffer disability resulting from levodopa-induced motor complications that cannot be satisfactorily controlled with drug manipulation. Another indication is intractable tremors not responding to anticholinergics.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with dyspnea and chest discomfort. A thoracentesis is performed, and the pleural fluid is sent for analysis. Which of the following criteria—known as Light’s criteria—is used to classify an effusion as exudative?

Explanation: Light’s criteria help distinguish exudative from transudative effusions. An effusion is classified as exudative if any one of the following is true:
• Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5
• Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.6
• Pleural fluid LDH > two-thirds the upper limit of normal for serum LDH
Option A is one of these classic criteria. In contrast, options C and D refer to parameters that are not part of Light’s criteria, and option B (a lower ratio of LDH) would be more consistent with a transudate.

Conduction aphasia comes from lesions of the superior temporal lobe or the inferior parietal region, and is marked by inability to repeat, with relatively preserved speech production (aside from mild paraphasic errors) and preserved speech comprehension. Due to the surrounding anatomical structures, symptoms that often accompany conduction aphasia include apraxia of the left side, right hemiparesis, right sensory loss, or right-sided hemianopsia.

questions.text: Regarding the bispectral index (BIS):
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• It is a weighted sum of several EEG parameters and provides the user with a dimensionless number which ranges from 0 (equivalent to EEG silence) to 100 (normal cortical electrical activity). 
• It records the cortical activity of a patient’s brain and, using analysis, gives a raw figure, higher values representing higher levels of cortical activity
• BIS is best described as a monitor of the depth of the hypnotic component of anaesthesia or sedation. 
• Bispectral index values
• 80–100 Awake, capable of specific recall
• 60–80 Increased sedation, impaired memory but rousable
• 40–60 Surgical plane of anaesthesia. Auditory processing and reflex movement are possible, but memory unlikely
• 60-40 deep hypnotic state
• 40-20 Burst suppression
• 0 flat line ( eeg silence)

BIS values only give an idea of cortical activity – they cannot distinguish whether a low value is due to anaesthesia or pathological causes of reduced consciousness.

questions.text: Which of the following best differentiates “delirium” from “dementia”? (NEET)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Fluctuating course (Ref : Kaplan)

A number of clinical features help distinguish delirium from dementia. The major differential points between dementia and delirium are the time to development of the condition and the fluctuation in level of attention in delirium compared with relatively consistent attention in dementia. 
The time to development of symptoms is usually short in delirium, and except for vascular dementia caused by stroke, it is usually gradual and insidious in dementia. Although both conditions include cognitive impairment, the changes in dementia are more stable over time and, for example, usually do not fluctuate over the course of a day. 
A patient with dementia is usually alert; a patient with delirium has episodes of decreased consciousness.

questions.text: Concerning etomidate:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

• Etomidate is an imidazole hypnotic, with a very stable haemodynamic profile and minimal respiratory depression. 
• To increase solubility, it is formulated as a 0.2 % solution either in 35 % propylene glycol 
• Etomidate has a very stable haemodynamic profile and minimal respiratory depression but, due to the inhibition of adrenocortical steroid synthesis either after a single dose or with drug infusion, the popularity of etomidate has declined. 
• It can cause hypnosis through its action on the GABA receptor system.
• Etomidate reduces CBF and CMRO2 while maintaining the MAP and CPP.
• An induction dose of etomidate of 0.3 mg/kg reduces intra-ocular pressure.
• Administration of etomidate has been associated with grand mal seizures and it also seems to cause myoclonic movements (which is not associated with seizure-like activity on EEG).
• Etomidate causes maximum pain on injection amongst IV induction agents.

questions.text: A 52 years old male a case of NHL received 1st cycle chemotherapy with CHOP ten days. He presented to causality with c/o muscle twitches, cramps, carpopedal spasm, paresthesia. His initial investigations revealed hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hyperuricemia. What is the most likely cause for the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Spontaneous or treatment-induced cell death leads to tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). 
• It occurs most frequently following the administration of cytotoxic chemotherapy to patients with hematologic malignancies, where a large percentage of cells are proliferating and drug sensitive. 
• Cell death leads to the release of potassium, phosphate, uric acid, and other purine metabolites, overwhelming the kidney’s capacity for clearance with resultant hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia and secondary hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia. Significant increases in serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) occur frequently.
• Unchecked, TLS can progress to lactic acidosis and acute renal failure. 
• Treatment includes intravenous fluids, allopurinol, and especially rasburicase (when uric acid >8 mg/dL, contraindicated with G6PD deficiency as can cause hemolysis and methemoglobinemia- i.e. male African/Mediterranean/SE asian ancestry)) and temporary haemodialysis.
• Urinary alkalnization NOT indicated as it can worsen Ca-Phos nephropathy

questions.text: In which of the following conditions anti thyroid antibody may not be elevated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Antibodies include antithyroglobulin (anti-Tg), antimicrosomal or antithyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) and thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI). Anti-Tg and anti-TPO antibody levels   they indicate the underlying disorder, usually an autoimmune thyroiditis. Approximately 80% of patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis have elevated thyroid antibody levels, but levels may also be increased in patients with Graves' disease, multinodular goiter, and, occasionally, with thyroid neoplasms
In Grave's disease antibodies are directed against (TRAbs) (thyroid hormone receptors) (TSI

questions.text: A 12 year old girl presented to the OPD with abdominal colic, nausea, diarrhoea and lethargy and headache for last 1 year. Her irritability and anger increased since last few months and she presented to emergency with weakness of lower limbs. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acute Intermittent Porphyria. 
(Ref : Kaplan and sadock synopsis chapter 21, 11th edition)
 
The porphyrias are disorders of heme biosynthesis that result in excessive accumulation of porphyrins. The triad of symptoms is acute, colicky abdominal pain; motor polyneuropathy; and psychosis. Acute intermittent porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder that affects more women than men and has its onset between ages 20 and 50 years. The psychiatric symptoms include anxiety, insomnia, lability of mood, depression, and psychosis. Symptoms of this disease also predominately include psychosis, apathy, or depression, along with intermittent abdominal pain, neuropathy, and autonomic dysfunction. Elevated levels of porphobilinogen are found in the urine of symptomatic patients with acute intermittent porphyria.
 
(There is no evidence of presence of acute precipitating stress factor, nor is there any ascending weakness)

choices.text: Amide local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized by plasma cholinesterase
Metabolism of bupivacaine is independent of hepatic function
Ester local anaesthetics are rapidly metabolized in by kidneys.
Metabolites from ester hydrolysis are excreted in the urine

questions.text: Metabolism of local anaesthetics depends on chemical structure.which of the  following statements about the same are true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

• Ester local anaesthetics undergo rapid metabolism by pseudocholinesterase enzymes. 
• The rapid hydrolysis in plasma results in water-soluble metabolites, which are excreted in urine.
• No metabolism occurs in cerebrospinal fluid and therefore intrathecally placed ester anaesthetics must be absorbed into the vascular system prior to metabolism. 
• Amide local anaesthetics are primarily metabolized by microsomal P450 enzymes in the liver.
• Bupivacaine, as an amide, is metabolized in the liver. 
• It is conjugated to glucuronic acid with only 5% excreted unchanged in the urine. 
• Hepatic failure generally has to be severe before metabolism is significantly affected.

questions.text: False statement about papillary thyroid cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

(Hurthle cell is a subtype of follicular cell cancer)
Papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) represents 70-75% of thyroid carcinomas. 
• PTC is often multifocal and frequently metastasizes to cervical lymph nodes. 
• A young age at diagnosis is a favorable prognostic factor, and even involvement of cervical nodes does not affect the prognosis adversely.
• Total thyroidectomy is appropriate for patients with gross evidence of bilateral disease, multifocal PTC, or a history of neck irradiation or for unilateral tumors larger than 1 to 1.5 cm. 
• Complications of total thyroidectomy include hypoparathyroidism and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) injury (1%). 
• Prophylactic node dissection has no role in papillary cancer but patients with clinically evident lymph node involvement should undergo ipsilateral central or lateral neck dissection at the time of thyroidectomy (Functional neck dissection).
• Radioablation of metastatic or residual cancer and residual thyroid tissue is performed with 75 to 100 mCi (Mili Curie) of 131I at 4 weeks after total thyroidectomy.
• Lifelong long-term suppression of TSH therapy with thyroid hormone replacement decreases recurrences and may improve survival.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with severe headache, vomiting, blurred vision, and altered mental status. His blood pressure is recorded as 180/120 mmHg (>99th percentile + 30 mmHg for age and height). Fundoscopy shows bilateral papilledema, and there is a mild elevation of serum creatinine. He is diagnosed with hypertensive emergency. The pediatric ICU is alerted and intravenous antihypertensive therapy is initiated. You are consulted for advice on how rapidly his blood pressure should be lowered to prevent complications such as cerebral hypoperfusion, seizures, and further renal damage.
What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding the initial reduction in blood pressure in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

10% reduction in first hour

Explanation:

In pediatric hypertensive emergencies, careful and gradual reduction of blood pressure is essential to prevent ischemic injury to vital organs. Sudden or aggressive lowering of blood pressure can compromise cerebral, coronary, and renal perfusion, particularly in children with chronic hypertension whose autoregulatory thresholds have shifted.

 • It impairs fertility and reduces success of IVF due to toxic fluid reflux
 • Laparoscopic salpingectomy improves IVF outcomes

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought with a history of brief flexor spasms occurring in clusters, especially on awakening. Developmental regression has been noted by the parents. EEG reveals a chaotic, high-voltage, disorganized pattern with multifocal spikes — a finding known as hypsarrhythmia. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ACTH

Explanation

Hypsarrhythmia is the classic EEG pattern seen in infantile spasms (West syndrome), which typically presents between 3 and 12 months of age with:

Clusters of epileptic spasms (flexor or extensor)

Developmental delay or regression

Characteristic chaotic EEG (hypsarrhythmia)

The drug of choice is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). High-dose intramuscular ACTH is considered first-line therapy in many guidelines, particularly for cryptogenic (no identifiable cause) infantile spasms. It is thought to modulate the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis and reduce abnormal brain activity.

Other effective treatments include:

Vigabatrin (especially in tuberous sclerosis-related spasms)

Oral steroids (prednisolone) in resource-limited settings

Carbamazepine, phenytoin, and phenobarbital are not effective for infantile spasms and are not recommended as first-line therapy.

Thus, the correct answer is A. ACTH.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient on ski vacation brought to emergency room for acute respiratory distress. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

High altitude lung edema produces image findings of acute lung injury edema: Alveolar edema with no, or little, interstitial edema; pulmonary vessels that are normal in caliber; and a heart of normal size. The distribution of edema fluid may be asymmetric and patchy, as in this case, for unknown reasons. This form of edema is believed to result from so-called stress failure of pulmonary capillaries (a form of acute structural lung injury) due to acute, severe capillary hypertension. Usually, computed tomography is not necessary to confidently suggest this diagnosis when the context is known.

questions.text: 22-year-old woman with primary infertility undergoes HSG, which shows the following. Which of the following is the most commonly associated anomaly?

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman undergoing ovulation induction for IVF presents with abdominal distension, nausea, and shortness of breath 6 days after hCG trigger. Ultrasound shows the following. What is the most likely underlying pathophysiological mechanism in this condition?

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with infertility. He has small, firm testes, gynecomastia, and sparse facial hair. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. Serum FSH and LH are elevated, and testosterone is low. What is the most likely karyotype, and what is a common associated finding?

 • Most common cause of male hypogonadism and infertility

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation visits the antenatal clinic for a routine check-up. On abdominal examination, the uterus appears smaller than expected for gestational age (corresponding to 16 weeks). Ultrasound reveals oligohydramnios, but fetal heart activity is present. Which of the following fetal conditions is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Renal agenesis

Explanation

Oligohydramnios (reduced amniotic fluid volume) is most commonly associated with fetal urinary tract abnormalities, especially in the second trimester. One of the most classic causes is bilateral renal agenesis, where the fetus fails to produce urine, a major component of amniotic fluid after the first trimester.

Key points:

In bilateral renal agenesis, the fetus produces no urine, leading to severe oligohydramnios and characteristic Potter sequence (facial anomalies, limb deformities, pulmonary hypoplasia).

Fetal anemia typically causes hydrops fetalis with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

Fetal jaundice is not a direct cause of altered amniotic fluid volume.

Anencephaly is associated with polyhydramnios due to impaired swallowing of amniotic fluid.

Thus, in the context of a small uterus and oligohydramnios at 18 weeks, the most likely diagnosis is A. Renal agenesis.

questions.text: A pediatrician is explaining patterns of inheritance to medical students using examples of genetic disorders. She describes a condition that commonly presents with recurrent respiratory infections, failure to thrive, and steatorrhea in early childhood. The disorder is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene and follows an autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance. Which of the following conditions best fits this description?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Cystic Fibrosis

Explanation

Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a classic autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, most commonly ΔF508. It affects chloride transport across epithelial cells, leading to thick mucus in the lungs, pancreas, and GI tract. Clinical features include:

Recurrent pulmonary infections

Pancreatic insufficiency and malabsorption

Meconium ileus in neonates

Male infertility (congenital absence of vas deferens)

Inheritance patterns of the other options:

Osteogenesis imperfecta: Most commonly autosomal dominant (COL1A1/COL1A2 mutations)

Treacher Collins Syndrome: Typically autosomal dominant (TCOF1 gene mutations)

Achondroplasia: Autosomal dominant, usually due to FGFR3 mutation; often new/sporadic mutations

Thus, among the listed options, Cystic Fibrosis is the correct answer as an autosomal recessive disorder.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric genetics clinic due to developmental delay, hypotonia, and insatiable appetite that has resulted in rapid weight gain over the last year. He was born at term following an uneventful pregnancy and showed poor feeding in the neonatal period. On examination, he has almond-shaped eyes, a narrow bifrontal diameter, and small hands and feet. There is no history of seizures. Genetic testing reveals a deletion in the paternal copy of chromosome 15q11–q13. The physician explains to the parents that this condition is due to a genetic phenomenon involving parent-of-origin specific gene expression.

Which of the following conditions shares a similar mechanism involving genomic imprinting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Angelman syndrome

Explanation:

The child described has clinical features consistent with Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS), a classic example of a disorder caused by genomic imprinting. PWS results from the loss of function of paternally inherited genes on chromosome 15q11–q13. The maternal copy of these genes is normally imprinted (silenced), so a deletion or defect in the paternal allele leads to disease.

Angelman syndrome (AS), although presenting with different clinical features (e.g., ataxia, seizures, happy demeanor), is also caused by disruption of genes on chromosome 15q11–q13, but it involves loss of the maternal allele, with the paternal allele being imprinted. Hence, both disorders involve genomic imprinting of the same chromosomal region but differ by the parent of origin.

DiGeorge syndrome is caused by 22q11.2 deletion, Williams syndrome involves a deletion at 7q11.23, and Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant condition—none of which are related to imprinting.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman complains of frothy greenish vaginal discharge with a foul odor and severe vulvar itching. On speculum exam, the cervix shows following appearance. What is the next best step in diagnosis?

Explanation:

 • NAAT is more sensitive, but wet mount is immediate and diagnostic in most cases

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Preimplantation Genetic Diagnosis (PGD) is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 PGD requires in vitro fertilization and is typically done on blastomeres or trophectoderm cells

Explanation:
 • PGD is a technique used during IVF cycles to genetically test embryos before uterine transfer.
 • It helps detect monogenic disorders, structural chromosomal abnormalities, or aneuploidies.
 • It is typically done at:
 • Day 3: Blastomere biopsy (6–8 cell stage)
 • Day 5: Trophectoderm biopsy (blastocyst stage)
 • Option A is wrong: PGD is done before implantation.
 • Option B is wrong: It’s used in ART, not in natural pregnancies.
 • Option D is wrong: It’s especially indicated in couples with known monogenic disorders (e.g., thalassemia, cystic fibrosis).

questions.text: 65-year-old woman with a history of vaginal hysterectomy 10 years ago now presents with a sensation of vaginal bulge and incomplete bowel emptying. Examination reveals vault prolapse. Which of the following is the most definitive surgical management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Sacrocolpopexy
Vault prolapse = prolapse of vaginal apex after hysterectomy
 • Sacrocolpopexy is the gold standard surgical procedure for apical (vault) prolapse, especially in sexually active or fit patients
 • It involves attaching the vaginal vault to the sacral promontory using mesh

choices.text: Decreased sympathetic tone due to progesterone
Compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus
Aorto-caval compression leading to reduced uterine blood flow

questions.text: 32-year-old woman in her third trimester becomes lightheaded and nauseous when lying flat for an ultrasound. Her BP drops to 80/50 mmHg. She recovers quickly when turned to the left lateral position. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Compression of the inferior vena cava by the gravid uterus
Explanation:
 • Supine hypotension syndrome (also called aortocaval compression syndrome) occurs when the gravid uterus compresses the inferior vena cava while the patient lies supine.
 • This reduces venous return, causing hypotension, dizziness, pallor, and sometimes fetal distress.
 • Relieved by left lateral tilt or turning to left lateral position.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of hearing concerns. The parents report that the baby does not respond to sounds or turn the head toward voices. On examination, bilateral lens opacities (cataracts) are noted, and a cardiac murmur is heard. Echocardiography confirms the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). There is no history of perinatal complications or NICU stay. Antenatal records show the mother had a mild febrile illness with rash in the first trimester. The clinician suspects a congenital infection as the underlying cause of the multisystem involvement.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Congenital rubella syndrome

Explanation:

Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) is a classic TORCH infection that presents with a triad of:

Sensorineural deafness

Congenital cataracts

Cardiac defects, especially PDA or pulmonary artery stenosis

These findings strongly suggest CRS, particularly when the maternal infection occurs in the first trimester, which carries the highest risk of vertical transmission and teratogenesis.

CMV may cause sensorineural hearing loss and periventricular calcifications, but not PDA or cataracts.

Toxoplasmosis often causes chorioretinitis and intracranial calcifications (diffuse or basal ganglia), not PDA.

HSV usually presents with vesicular skin lesions, encephalitis, or disseminated disease—cardiac and eye anomalies are uncommon.

Hence, the constellation of deafness, cataract, and PDA is most specific for congenital rubella syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common long-term complication of the condition shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Infertility

Explanation: this is an image of pelvic inflammatory disease which has high risk of infertility 
 • Due to tubal scarring and blockage from inflammation.
 • Infertility risk increases with each recurrent episode of PID.
 • Ectopic pregnancy and chronic pain are also important but less frequent.

choices.text: Iron-folic acid supplementation should begin from the third trimester
A minimum of 6 antenatal visits are recommended, starting after the second trimester
Tetanus-diphtheria (Td) vaccine is given only once in each pregnancy
First antenatal check-up should ideally be done within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy

questions.text: According to the current Indian national guidelines (MOHFW), which of the following statements about antenatal care is TRUE?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

First antenatal check-up should ideally be done within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy
Explanation:
 • Antenatal visits: At least 4 minimum 
 • First ANC: Before 12 weeks (ideally as early as possible) – Option D is correct.
 • IFA supplementation: Begins from second trimester (Option A is incorrect.
 • Td vaccine: Usually 2 doses in the first pregnancy, 1 booster in subsequent pregnancies – Option C is incorrect.
 • Visits start early, not after second trimester – Option B is incorrect.

questions.text: A full-term newborn is evaluated at 24 hours of life. The baby is active, feeding well on exclusive breastfeeding, and has stable vital signs. However, the parents are concerned because the baby has not passed urine since birth. There is no abdominal distension, vomiting, or signs of dehydration. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Continue breastfeeding and observe

Explanation

It is normal for full-term newborns to pass urine within the first 24 to 48 hours of life. By 24 hours, more than 90% of newborns would have voided, but a small proportion of healthy infants may not urinate until slightly later, especially if breastfeeding has just been established and fluid intake is low in the first day.

In the absence of warning signs such as:

Abdominal distension

Signs of obstruction

Vomiting

Dehydration

Poor feeding or lethargy

The appropriate next step is to continue breastfeeding and observe. Encourage frequent feeding and monitor for urine output in the next few hours.

IV fluids are not indicated unless there are signs of dehydration.

Formula feeds are not necessary if breastfeeding is adequate.

NICU admission and antibiotics are unnecessary unless there is clinical suspicion of sepsis or obstruction.

Thus, the best approach is C. Continue breastfeeding and observe.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, 3 days postpartum, presents with fever, lower abdominal pain, and foul-smelling lochia. Uterus is tender and subinvoluted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Puerperal sepsis (endometritis)
Explanation:
 • Classic signs of postpartum endometritis:
 • Fever >38°C
 • Uterine tenderness
 • Foul-smelling lochia
 • Occurs commonly within 2–5 days postpartum
 • Risk factors: prolonged labor, multiple vaginal exams, cesarean delivery

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant, born to an HIV-positive mother, presents with recurrent diarrhea. The baby was exclusively breastfed and has no other significant medical history. On examination, the infant is mildly dehydrated but hemodynamically stable. Given the age and high-risk background, what is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 HIV PCR on dried blood spot

Explanation

In infants <24 months of age, HIV antibody testing is not reliable due to the persistence of maternal antibodies, which can give false-positive results. Therefore, virologic testing (HIV DNA/PCR) is the standard met…

choices.text: Start ART immediately and plan elective cesarean at 38 weeks
Delay ART until 34 weeks and plan for vaginal delivery
Start ART immediately and allow vaginal delivery irrespective of viral load
ART not needed as CD4 count is >200 and viral load is low

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman at 30 weeks gestation is diagnosed with HIV. Her viral load is 900 copies/mL and CD4 count is 420 cells/mm³. She is not on ART. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Start ART immediately and allow vaginal delivery irrespective of viral load
Explanation (As per NACO 2024 Guidelines):
 • ART initiation: All pregnant women diagnosed with HIV should be started on lifelong ART immediately, regardless of CD4 count or viral load.
 • Viral load testing: Done at baseline and again between 32- 36 weeks, but not to decide mode of delivery.
 • Mode of delivery: Vaginal delivery is recommended unless obstetric indications dictate otherwise. Cesarean is not done solely based on viral load in NACO guidelines (unlike some international protocols).
 • Option A is incorrect because cesarean at 38 weeks is not mandatory for viral load <1000 copies/mL.
 • Option B is incorrect — ART should not be delayed.
 • Option D is incorrect — ART is required regardless of CD4 count or viral load.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea. She has no secondary sexual characteristics. Height is below the 3rd percentile, and she has a webbed neck and shield chest. all the following are true about this condition except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

High risk of gonadal malignancy
Gonadal malignancy risk is high in Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome or gonadal dysgenesis with Y chromosome (e.g., Swyer syndrome), not classic 45,XO Turner.

questions.text: Most common fetal complication of vacuum delivery is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cephalohematoma
Vacuum-assisted delivery increases the risk of:
 • Cephalohematoma (most common):
→ Subperiosteal hemorrhage
→ Limited to one bone, does not cross suture lines
 • Other possible (but less common) complications:
 • Retinal hemorrhage
 • Scalp laceration
 • Neonatal jaundice (due to hematoma resorption)

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the emergency room with a 2-day history of diarrhea. On examination, the child is lethargic, unable to drink or feed, and has a skin pinch that goes back slowly. Mucous membranes are dry and the child has sunken eyes. Based on WHO classification of dehydration, what is the most appropriate classification of this child’s hydration status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Severe dehydration

Explanation

The WHO classification for dehydration in children with diarrhea is based on clinical signs and grouped into three categories:

No dehydration: Alert, normal feeding, skin pinch returns immediately.

Some dehydration: Restless/irritable, drinks eagerly, skin pinch goes back slowly.

Severe dehydration: Lethargic or unconscious, not able to drink or drinks poorly, skin pinch goes back very slowly (>2 seconds).

In this case:

Lethargy

Inability to feed

Skin pinch returning slowly

These findings are consistent with severe dehydration. The skin pinch may go back slowly in both "some" and "severe" dehydration, but lethargy and inability to feed are defining features of severe dehydration.

Note: "Moderate dehydration" is not a formal WHO category; it overlaps with "some dehydration" but is not used in WHO protocols.

Thus, the correct answer is C. Severe dehydration.

questions.text: A male patient with diarrhea since 8months with shown CT finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Chronic diarrhea with CT showing loss of haustrations suggests ulcerative colitis.
It typically involves the colon in a continuous pattern. Thus, ulcerative colitis is the likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindication for performing dilatation and curettage (D&C)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Suspected uterine perforation
Explanation:
 • Suspected uterine perforation is an absolute contraindication to D&C due to the risk of exacerbating the injury or causing visceral damage.
 • In such cases, further instrumentation is avoided until diagnosis is confirmed (often via imaging or laparoscopy).

Other options are common indications for D&C or do not preclude it.

questions.text: Primigravida in labor is found to have a fetus in vertex presentation with occiput posterior position and  deflexion of the head. Which of the following is the most likely engaging diameter of the fetal head in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Occipitofrontal
Explanation:
 • Occipitoposterior with mild deflexion → the head is not fully flexed
 • Engaging diameter in this scenario is occipitofrontal (~11.5 cm)
 • Extends from occipital prominence to glabella (forehead)

questions.text: Most useful investigation for localization of parathyroid adenoma:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Sestamibi scan is highly sensitive for parathyroid adenomas. It uses Tc-99m radiotracer to localize hyperfunctioning glands. Therefore, it is the investigation of choice.

questions.text:
A preterm newborn presents within the first few hours of life with signs of respiratory distress, including chest retractions, nasal flaring, tachypnea, and lethargy. The oxygen saturation is low despite supplemental oxygen. Chest X-ray shows a reticulogranular pattern with air bronchograms. The pediatrician suspects Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). Further review of the baby's antenatal history reveals no antenatal corticosteroid administration. The diagnosis is confirmed, and the cause is identified as a deficiency of a key component that reduces alveolar surface tension, leading to alveolar collapse.

Which of the following is most likely deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Lecithin

Explanation:

Neonatal Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), especially common in preterm infants, is caused by a deficiency of pulmonary surfactant, which is crucial for reducing alveolar surface tension and preventing atelectasis. The most important component of surfactant is Dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC), commonly known as lecithin.

Lecithin production increases significantly after 32–34 weeks of gestation, and its levels can be measured in amniotic fluid. A Lecithin:Sphingomyelin (L:S) ratio >2 usually indicates sufficient lung maturity. Sphingomyelin levels remain relatively constant and serve as a reference in this ratio. Dipalmitoylphosphatidylethanolamine and dipalmitoyl inositol are not primary surfactant components.

Therefore, the deficiency of lecithin (DPPC) is the key biochemical defect in neonatal RDS. Treatment involves administration of exogenous surfactant and supportive respiratory care.

questions.text: Best initial treatment for mild to moderate endometriosis in a woman not seeking fertility:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Combined oral contraceptives
First-line treatment for symptom control (especially pain and dysmenorrhea)
 • Provide hormonal suppression → reduce cyclical endometrial proliferation
 • Suppress ovulation and menstruation → reduce retrograde menstruation
 • Also offer contraceptive benefit, which is ideal in this scenario

questions.text: Which of the following surgical procedure will you do for the Müllerian anomaly shown below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Strassman
This is bicornuate uterus and needs surgical unification called Strassman metroplasty

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents with cyclical lower abdominal pain for 6 months and has not attained menarche. She has normal secondary sexual characteristics. On examination, a tender pelvic mass is palpable, and bluish bulging membrane is seen at the vaginal introitus. What is the most likely immediate complication if left untreated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Urinary retention
This is a classic presentation of imperforate hymen causing cryptomenorrhea and hematocolpos.
 • The accumulated blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) exerts pressure on the bladder and urethra, leading to:
 • Acute urinary retention — the most immediate complication
 • May also cause hydronephrosis if prolonged
 • Endometriosis is a delayed complication due to retrograde menstruation.
 • PID is unlikely (no ascending infection with intact hymen).
 • Intrauterine adhesions = Asherman syndrome (usually post-D&C or infections)
